Award.AwardTitle: Fundamental Investigations on System-Level Cost Evaluation for Economic Viability of Cellulosic Biofuel Manufacturing

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research can enable expanded production of ethanol from wood and other cellulose-based feedstocks by lowering the cost of production. This will contribute to resolving two major issues: energy shortage and global warming. Consequently, the success of this research will help improve the economic viability of the U.S. ethanol manufacturing industry, reduce oil dependence, and benefit the environment and society in terms of greenhouse gas emissions reduction. In a carbon-constrained world, this research will serve to green the U.S. transportation sector, and provide a competitive advantage to the U.S. renewable energy industry. This project will closely integrate with the training of graduate as well as undergraduate students, especially female and underrepresented minority students. The ideas and results will be broadly disseminated through classroom teachings, conference presentations, and journal publications.

The research objective of this grant is to generate new knowledge to build a system-level cost model for cellulosic biofuel manufacturing utilizing the interrelations among major individual manufacturing processes and to establish the methodology for system-level cost-effective decision making to improve the economic viability of cellulosic biofuel manufacturing under the constraint of ethanol yield. First, existing experimental results will be analyzed to obtain the interrelations among individual cellulosic biofuel manufacturing processes. Then these obtained interrelations will be used to construct a system-level cost model for cellulosic biofuel manufacturing. Based on this model, a cost-effective decision making tool will be established to reduce the overall cost while maintaining the ethanol yield target of cellulosic biofuel manufacturing. Finally, experimental validations and scalability investigations of research results will be performed.

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
For the intellectual merit, previous research on cellulosic biofuel manufacturing has mainly focused on individual cellulosic biofuel manufacturing processes. However, there is no guarantee that separately optimized parameters of each process will lead to cost savings for the entire biofuel manufacturing system. Therefore, it is more important and meaningful to consider the interrelations between individual processes and analyze the cost effectiveness of multiple processes simultaneously and systematically. This research fills the gap in the literature and generate new knowledge for cellulosic biofuel manufacturing: (1) the system-level cost model for cellulosic biofuel manufacturing utilizing the interrelations among major individual manufacturing processes has been built; and (2) the methodology for system-level cost-effective decision making to improve the economic viability of cellulosic biofuel manufacturing under the constraint of ethanol yield has been established. Major research tasks completed include: (1) energy efficiency improvement in biomass feedstock preprocessing under the constraint of production target; (2) production modeling and optimal control for cellulosic biofuel production processes; (3) system-level cost evaluation for economic viability of cellulosic biofuel manufacturing; (4) economic evaluation of lignocellulosic biofuel manufacturing considering integrated lignin waste conversion to hydrocarbon fuels; (5) joint energy and production control of biomass feedstock chemical conversion; (6) industrial-scale cellulase enzyme production optimal design; and (7) laboratory development of a simulation testbed for cellulosic biofuel production and cellulase enzyme manufacturing. Based on these tasks, seven journal papers have been published in various peer-reviewed journals and one conference paper has been published. Three journal papers and one U.S. patent have been submitted and under review. 

 

For the broader impacts, the proposed research can facilitate expanded production of cellulosic biofuels as renewable liquid transportation fuels and help to realize cost-effective cellulosic biofuel manufacturing, which will contribute to relieving two major issues to the human society: energy shortage and global warming. Consequently, the success of the proposed research will improve the economic viability of the U.S. cellulosic biofuel manufacturing industry, reduce oil dependence, and significantly benefit environment and society in terms of GHG emissions reduction. In a carbon-constrained world, this research serves to green the U.S. transportation sector, and provides a competitive advantage to the U.S. renewable energy industry. Research results have been incorporated into one graduate/undergraduate course at the University of Illinois at Chicago, IE442: Design and Analysis of Experiments in Engineering, hence positively affecting engineering education at the university. This project provides research assistantship support to one Ph.D. student and one graduate student. Two undergraduate students (one female student) are also involved in this project through the NSF REU support, collecting the data in the research laboratory and analyzing cost issues in cellulosic biofuel manufacturing. Furthermore, a summer camp has been held to the K-12 students by demonstrating the simulation model based on Aspen Plus to encourage K-12 students to explore their personal interests in the engineering field.


Last Modified: 07/18/2019
Modified by: Lin Li
